page.title: 05Conservation in Wharton Wood
page.content: The main conservation and preservation work in Wharton Wood invovles the tree life. This includes planting, weeding, brashing (removing the lower branches for easy thoroughfare this takes place when he trees are about 6 metres tall), thinning (which is to remove some of the young trees to prevent overcrowdinglater on, this takes place every 5 years). When the trees are first planted they are planted in white hollow cones for protection and later wire is put around them to stop rabbits and squirrels from stripping the bark and sucking the sap. When a tree is mature it is chopped down and sent to the saw mills.
